title: 110_s1146
content: The "Rural Veterans Health Care Improvement Act of 2007" includes provisions for travel reimbursement for veterans receiving treatment at Department of Veterans Affairs facilities and establishes Centers for Rural Health Research, Education, and Clinical Activities. The "Rural Veterans Health Care Improvement Act of 2007" establishes Centers for rural health research, education, and clinical activities to conduct research, develop models, and provide education for health services in rural areas. The "Rural Veterans Health Care Improvement Act of 2007" establishes Centers for rural health research, education, and clinical activities to provide innovative health services to veterans in rural areas. The Secretary must ensure that these centers are geographically dispersed throughout the United States and meet high standards of scientific and clinical merit. The "Rural Veterans Health Care Improvement Act of 2007" establishes Centers for rural health research, education, and clinical activities to provide innovative health services to veterans in rural areas. These centers must have arrangements with accredited medical schools, attract scientists for research, have a policymaking advisory committee, and the capability to conduct research effectively. The Director of the Office of Rural Health will establish a panel to evaluate proposals for rural health centers, comprised of experts in public health research, education, and clinical care. Panel members will serve as consultants for up to two years. The panel, established by the Director of the Office of Rural Health, will evaluate proposals for rural health centers. It is not subject to the Federal Advisory Committee Act. Funding is authorized for research and education activities of the centers operated under this section. Activities of clinical and scientific investigation will be conducted at each center. The center operated under this section is eligible for funding from the Medical and Prosthetics Research Account, with priority given to projects for research in the care of rural veterans. A clerical amendment is made to the table of sections in the relevant title. "Transportation grants for rural veterans service organizations." The Secretary of Veterans Affairs will establish a grant program to provide innovative transportation options to veterans in remote rural areas. State veterans' service agencies and veterans service organizations can use the grants to help veterans travel to VA medical centers and provide medical care in remote rural areas. Grants may not exceed $50,000 and do not require matching funds from recipients. The Secretary will establish a grant program for innovative transportation options for veterans in remote rural areas. Grants can be used by state veterans' service agencies and veterans service organizations to help veterans travel to VA medical centers and provide medical care in remote rural areas. The Secretary will prescribe regulations for evaluating grant applications and administering the program. A veterans service organization is defined as an organization recognized by the Secretary of Veterans Affairs for representing veterans. $3,000,000 is authorized for each fiscal year from 2008 to 2012 for this section. "Section 5 establishes demonstration projects for expanding care for veterans in rural areas." The Secretary of Veterans Affairs will conduct demonstration projects to expand care for veterans in rural areas. This includes partnerships with Centers for Medicare and Medicaid Services and community health centers to coordinate care at critical access hospitals and community health centers. The Secretary of Veterans Affairs will expand care for Native American veterans by coordinating with the Indian Health Service. The demonstration projects will be geographically distributed throughout the United States, and a report on the results will be submitted to relevant committees in Congress within two years. The Secretary of Veterans Affairs will report to Congress on matters related to care for veterans who live in rural areas. The Secretary of Veterans Affairs will provide an annual report to Congress on the implementation of the provisions of the Act, including the establishment and function of the Office of Rural Health. Additionally, an assessment of the fee-basis health-care program will be included in the initial report. The fee-basis health-care program and outreach program required by the Veterans Benefits, Health Care, and Information Technology Act of 2006 will be reported to Congress annually, including an assessment in the initial report.
